I couldn't stop myself from counting days, so I went with it.

From 0-30 it felt like I could easily "get that time back" but my first try at sobriety I was in rehab and didn't want to fuck up, so I had no chance of relapsing.
31-60 days my sobriety felt more like, wow, it would take me TWO MONTHS to get back to where I am today. Might as well stay sober.
Up until 6 months I felt the same way.
After 6 months I was hit with a huge dilemma: I decided I needed to commit to long term sobriety. I realized I didn't have the resources to get this time back. Half a year is a long time.
Disclaimer: this is how my self-talk works. I worked quite hard through outpatient therapy and counselling to stop myself from self-sabotaging. I found that counting days until one year was really useful. Now I'll celebrate big milestones, like 2500 days...I'll bake a cake or something.

Many people have unhappy home lives, not everyone reaches for a bottle. Drinking was a choice I made to deal with life.
I found that when I got sober, I started to notice more of the family dynamics that were going on.
My husband didn't watch me go through active addiction, but we have issues like most couples. What really helped me was learning about our 'language of love'
For example, my husband doesn't show his love for me through flowery poetry or gifts. But I never have to put gas in the car, and he loves making the home safe and comfortable for me. His language of love is acts of service. I didn't realize he was basically saying "I love you" when the car was safe, the home was clean and the roof was mended.
To overcome some of our communication issues, we've had to sit down and actually talk about what we want from each other and how to navigate how we show affection.

In my experience, I get cravings when faced with difficult times (moving to Toronto away from my husband for a year) where I feel like my regular coping skills are going to be challenged.
It's like the old Victoria drinking brain kicks in and goes "HEY REMEMBER WHEN YOU USED TO DRINK THROUGH EVERYTHING, HEY REMEMBER THAT?"

For me when I write and talk about cravings, it reshines the light back onto the addiction. It exposes cravings for what they are in my mind: a very overvalued thought.
